facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 449 of 1969 filed as appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 449 of 1969. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order September 10, 1968 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court at Chandigarh in L.P. No. 108 of 1966.

facts.text: Punjab and Haryana High Court delivered judgment and order on September 10, 1968 in L.P.A. No. 108 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order September 10, 1968 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court at Chandigarh in L.P. No. 108 of 1966. C. Mahajan and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant.

facts.text: Respondent company dismissed three workmen between December 15, 1959 and January 6, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent companypany dismissed three of its workmen between the 15th December, 1959 and 6th January, 1960 and it also retrenched another employee on the 7th February 1960.

facts.text: Company retrenched another employee on February 7, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent companypany dismissed three of its workmen between the 15th December, 1959 and 6th January, 1960 and it also retrenched another employee on the 7th February 1960. The District Motor Transport Workers Union appears to have raised a dispute with the-management on the 17th November, 1960

facts.text: District Motor Transport Workers Union raised dispute on November 17, 1960 demanding reinstatement of dismissed workmen and retrenchment compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The District Motor Transport Workers Union appears to have raised a dispute with the-management on the 17th November, 1960 and demanded the reinstate- ment of the dismissed workmen as well as the payment of retrenchment companypensation regarding the workman who was retrenched.

facts.text: State Government declined to make reference on June 9, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On the 9th June, 1960, the State Government declined to make a reference. A further attempt was made to persuade the State Government by the workmen companycerned to make a reference, but that attempt also failed,

facts.text: State Government declined reference again on July 29, 1961 stating only 18 out of 60 workmen supported demand, including 13 dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In this order, the State Government had stated that out of sixty workmen employed in the companycern, only 18 workmen had supported the demand and these 18 included thirteen dismissed workers of the companypany.

facts.text: Only five of the 18 supporting workmen were in employment of company at relevant time.

anchor.surface_text: It is the further view of the Government that as a substantial number of workmen had number espoused the cause of the dismissed workmen, there was numberindustrial dispute which companyld be referred for adjudication. It is to be numbered from this order of the State Government that out of the 18 workmen,

facts.text: State Government referred dispute to Labour Court Rohtak on March 5, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Another attempt appears to have been made to induce the State Government to make a reference and this time the attempt succeeded, as will be seen from the order dated the 5th March, 1962.

facts.text: Reference concerned termination of services of Manmohan Singh, Jagir Singh, Inderjit Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government... referred for adjudication to the Labour Court, Rohtak, the following two questions - Whether termination of services of Sarvashri Manmohan Singh, Jagir Singh and Inderjit. Singh is justified and in order ?

facts.text: Reference concerned retrenchment of Shri Mohinder Singh, Booking Clerk.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the retrenchment of Shri Mohinder Singh, Booking Clerk, is justified, and in order ? If number, to what relief he is entitled ? When the Labour Court companymenced the, proceedings in respect of this dispute,

facts.text: Management raised preliminary objection that dispute not industrial dispute under section 2(k) as not espoused by substantial body of workmen.

anchor.surface_text: When the Labour Court companymenced the, proceedings in respect of this dispute, the management raised two preliminary objections. We are companycerned with only the first objection. namely, that the dispute that has been referred by the State Government for adjudication is number an industrial Dispute under section 2 k  of the Industrial Disputes Act

facts.text: Labour Court overruled management's preliminary objection.

anchor.surface_text: Tie Labour Court accepted the plea of the workmen that the dispute was industrial dispute and overruled the preliminary objection raised in that regard by the management.

facts.text: Company filed writ petition in High Court to quash Labour Court order and government reference.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany filed a writ petition in the High Court for quashing the order of the Labour Court as well as the. reference made by the State Government.

facts.text: Single Judge held reference incompetent as not sponsored by substantial body of workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single Judge accepted the plea of the management that the dispute in question had number been sponsored by a substantial body of the workmen of the respondent companypany, and in this view, held that the order of reference was incompetent.

facts.text: State filed Letters Patent Appeal against single Judge order; workmen did not challenge.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen did number challenge the decision of the single Judge. But the State challenged the same in Letters Patent Appeal before a Division Bench of the High Court.

facts.text: Division Bench confirmed single Judge holding reference incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench has agreed with the views of the learned single Judge and companyfirmed his order holding that the reference made by the State Government was incompetent.

facts.text: On November 17, 1960, there were sixty workmen in employ of respondent company.

anchor.surface_text: According to the findings of the learned single Judge, which have been accepted by the Division Bench. the position is that on the 17th November, 1960, when the espousal of the cause of the dismissed and retrenched workmen was made, there were sixty workmen

facts.text: Demand supported by 18 workmen: five in employ and thirteen dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: It has also been found that the demand was supported by 18 workmen, namely, five workmen, who were in the employ of the respondent and thirteen others, who had already been dismissed from service.

facts.text: High Court found five out of sixty not substantial body.

anchor.surface_text: The view of the High Court is that having due regard to the strength of the workmen, namely sixty, and the admitted position that only five of the workmen then in employ espoused the dispute, it cannot be stated that a substantial body of the workmen have espoused the cause

facts.text: Supreme Court held espousal by five out of sixty (1/12th) not appreciable or substantial.

anchor.surface_text: Even applying the ratio of the said decision- to the case on hand, the proportion is very low, being five to sixty. That means only 1/12th of the employees in the establishment of the management has espoused the cause of the dismissed workmen. Such an espousal, in our opinion, cannot be companysidered to be by an appreciable or substantial body of workmen

facts.text: No plea by workmen that union espoused the cause.

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection it must be stated that the workmen did number plead even before the Tribunal that any union, representative of the workmen, has taken up the dispute.

facts.text: Labour Court held no such plea by workmen of union espousal.

anchor.surface_text: In fact the Labour Court has held that numbersuch plea was taken by the workmen. The sponsoring by the 13 dismissed employees will have to be left out of companysideration.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed as no industrial dispute, reference incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: As there was numberIndustrial Dispute, the reference made by the State Government has been rightly held by the High Court to be, incompetent. The appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts of the first respondent.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order September 10, 1968 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court at Chandigarh in L.P. No. 108 of 1966.

This appeal, by special leave, is directed against the judgment and order dated the 10th September, 1968, of the Division Bench of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana in L.P.A. No. 108 of 1966, confirming the order of the learned single Judge and holding that the order of the State Government dated the 5th March, 1962 referring a dispute for adjudication was incompetent.

namely, that the dispute that has been referred by the State Government for adjudication is not an industrial Dispute under section 2 k  of the Industrial Disputes Act inasmuch as the cause of the workman had not been espoused by a substantial body of the workmen of the Company.

issues.text: Whether the dispute that has been referred by the State Government for adjudication is an industrial dispute under section 2(k) of the Industrial Disputes Act inasmuch as the cause of the workmen had not been espoused by a substantial body of the workmen of the Company.

anchor.surface_text: namely, that the dispute that has been referred by the State Government for adjudication is not an industrial Dispute under section 2 k  of the Industrial Disputes Act inasmuch as the cause of the workman had not been espoused by a substantial body of the workmen of the Company.

issues.text: Whether espousal of the cause of the dismissed and retrenched workmen by only five out of sixty workmen in employment constitutes espousal by a substantial or appreciable body of workmen so as to make it an industrial dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The view of the High Court is that having due regard to the strength of the workmen, namely sixty, and the admitted position that only five of the workmen then in employ espoused the dispute, it cannot be stated that a substantial body of the workmen have espoused the cause of the dismissed and retrenched employees.

issues.text: Whether the support of thirteen dismissed workmen can be counted towards espousal by a substantial body of workmen.

anchor.surface_text: In this order, the State Government had stated that out of sixty workmen employed in the concern, only 18 workmen had supported the demand and these 18 included thirteen dismissed workers of the company. It is the further view of the Government that as a substantial number of workmen had not espoused the cause of the dismissed workmen, there was no industrial dispute which could be referred for adjudication.

issues.text: Whether any union representative of the workmen espoused the cause of the dismissed workmen.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection it must be stated that the workmen did not plead even before the Tribunal that any union, representative of the workmen, has taken up the dispute.

issues.text: Whether the State Government has jurisdiction to refer a dispute for adjudication in the absence of an industrial dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government will have jurisdiction to make a reference only if there is an Industrial Dispute. As there was no Industrial Dispute, the reference made by the State Government has been rightly held by the High Court to be, incompetent.

arguments.claim: View of High Court erroneous; espousal by 5/60 constitutes appreciable/substantial body following Rohtak precedent where 5/22 sufficient.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. V. C. Mahajan, learned counsel for the appellant, has no doubt strenuously urged that the view of the learned single Judge and the Division Bench is erroneous. In support of his contention, the learned counsel referred to us the decision of this Court in Workmen of Rohtak General Transport Company v. Rohtak General Transport Company . He pointed out that the facts in that case show that though only five out of twenty-two workmen espoused the cause of the dismissed employee, it was held by this Court that five workmen could be considered to form a substantial or appreciable body of the workmen of the company and hence there was an industrial dispute giving power to the Government to refer the same for adjudication. Based upon this decision, the counsel urged that as it has been found in the present case that out of the total of sixty workmen, five have supported the cause of the workmen concerned, it must also be held that there has been an espousal of the dispute by an appreciable number of the employees of the company and that there is an industrial dispute, which was properly referred by the Government.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to the strength of the workmen, namely sixty, and the admitted position that only five of the workmen then in employ espoused the dispute, it cannot b

arguments.court_reasoning: Ratio not absolute; proportion 1/12th too low; Rohtak distinguishable due to union espousal, resolutions by all employees, unchallenged evidence.

arguments.claim: Espousal by 5 out of 60 (1/12th) cannot be considered appreciable or substantial body of workmen.

anchor.surface_text: Even applying the ratio of the said decision- to the case on hand, the proportion is very low, being five to sixty. That means only 1/12th of the employees in the establishment of the management has espoused the cause of the dismissed workmen. Such an espousal, in our opinion, cannot be considered to be by an appreciable or substantial body of workmen so, as to constitute the dispute an industrial dispute.

arguments.claim: Rohtak decision distinguishable; relied on resolutions by all employees supporting cause and union taking it up; management did not challenge evidence.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the above decision does not lay down the proposition that whenever five out of twenty-two workmen sponsor a dispute or in such proportion, there is always an espousal of the cause by a substantial or appreciable body of workmen so as to make the dispute an industrial dispute. No such proposition, in our opinion, is laid down by this Court in the said decision. If the said decision is carefully read, it will be clear that the workmen therein relied on certain resolutions passed by all the employees of the company supporting the cause of the dismissed workmen. Further, there was also material on record to show that the cause of dismissed employees was taken up by a union. It was in view of all these circumstances, added to the fact that the management therein had not challenged those items of evidence, that this Court held in the particular circumstances of that case that there has been a proper espousal of the cause of the dismissed employees so as to make the dispute an industrial dispute. This decision, therefore, does not give any assistance to the appellant.

arguments.claim: Workmen did not plead that any representative union took up the dispute.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection it must be stated that the workmen did not plead even before the Tribunal that any union, representative of the workmen, has taken up the dispute.

arguments.claim: No plea taken by workmen of union espousal; sponsoring by 13 dismissed employees excluded from consideration.

anchor.surface_text: In fact the Labour Court has held that no such plea was taken by the workmen. The sponsoring by the 13 dismissed employees will have to be left out of consideration.

arguments.claim: State Government has jurisdiction to refer dispute only if it is an industrial dispute; here no such dispute so reference incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government will have jurisdiction to make a reference only if there is an Industrial Dispute. As there was no Industrial Dispute, the reference made by the State Government has been rightly held by the High Court to be, incompetent.

holdings.text: Such an espousal [by five out of sixty workmen], in our opinion, cannot be considered to be by an appreciable or substantial body of workmen so as to constitute the dispute an industrial dispute.

anchor.surface_text: Even applying the ratio of the said decision- to the case on hand, the proportion is very low, being five to sixty. That means only 1/12th of the employees in the establishment of the management has espoused the cause of the dismissed workmen. Such an espousal, in our opinion, cannot be considered to be by an appreciable or substantial body of workmen so, as to constitute the dispute an industrial dispute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied ratio from Rohtak but distinguished facts; proportion 1/12th too low.

holdings.text: It cannot in the circumstances, be held that there has been an espousal of the dispute in this case by an appreciable body of the workmen of the respondent-company so as to make it an Industrial Dispute.

anchor.surface_text: If so, we are left with the position that the espousal of the dispute, in this case, was only by five out of sixty employees of the respondent- company. It cannot in the circumstances, be held that there has been an espousal of the dispute in this case by an appreciable body of the workmen of the respondent-company so as to make it an Industrial Dispute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Only five current workmen espoused; dismissed excluded; no union plea.

holdings.text: The sponsoring by the 13 dismissed employees will have to be left out of consideration.

anchor.surface_text: In fact the Labour Court has held that no such plea was taken by the workmen. The sponsoring by the 13 dismissed employees will have to be left out of consideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dismissed workmen not in employment; only current workmen count for espousal.

holdings.text: The workmen did not plead even before the Tribunal that any union, representative of the workmen, has taken up the dispute.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection it must be stated that the workmen did not plead even before the Tribunal that any union, representative of the workmen, has taken up the dispute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No plea or evidence presented of union espousal before Labour Court or higher courts.

holdings.text: The State Government will have jurisdiction to make a reference only if there is an Industrial Dispute. As there was no Industrial Dispute, the reference made by the State Government has been rightly held by the High Court to be, incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government will have jurisdiction to make a reference only if there is an Industrial Dispute. As there was no Industrial Dispute, the reference made by the State Government has been rightly held by the High Court to be, incompetent. The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs of the first respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of industrial dispute deprives government of reference power under ID Act.

holdings.text: The above decision [Rohtak] does not lay down the proposition that whenever five out of twenty-two workmen sponsor a dispute or in such proportion, there is always an espousal of the cause by a substantial or appreciable body of workmen so as to make the dispute an industrial dispute.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the above decision does not lay down the proposition that whenever five out of twenty-two workmen sponsor a dispute or in such proportion, there is always an espousal of the cause by a substantial or appreciable body of workmen so as to make the dispute an industrial dispute. No such proposition, in our opinion, is laid down by this Court in the said decision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rohtak relied on resolutions by all employees, union involvement, unchallenged evidence; distinguishable.

anchor.surface_text: Even applying the ratio of the said decision- to the case on hand, the proportion is very low, being five to sixty. That means only 1/12th of the employees in the establishment of the management has espoused the cause of the dismissed workmen. Such an espousal, in our opinion, cannot be considered to be by an appreciable or substantial body of workmen so, as to constitute the dispute an industrial dispute.

anchor.surface_text: If so, we are left with the position that the espousal of the dispute, in this case, was only by five out of sixty employees of the respondent- company. It cannot in the circumstances, be held that there has been an espousal of the dispute in this case by an appreciable body of the workmen of the respondent-company so as to make it an Industrial Dispute.
The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs of the first respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government will have jurisdiction to make a reference only if there is an Industrial Dispute. As there was no Industrial Dispute, the reference made by the State Government has been rightly held by the High Court to be, incompetent. The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs of the first respondent.
